diseases.name: Bacterial Spot
diseases.definition: Bacterial Spot is a plant disease caused by the Xanthomonas species of bacteria.
diseases.history: First identified in the early 20th century, Bacterial Spot affects a variety of plants, including tomatoes and peppers.
diseases.symptoms: Symptoms include small, water-soaked spots on leaves, which may turn dark and cause leaf drop.
diseases.causes: The disease is caused by the bacteria Xanthomonas campestris pv. vesicatoria, which spread through water, infected seeds, and contaminated tools.
diseases.solutions: Management includes using disease-free seeds, applying copper-based bactericides, and practicing crop rotation.

diseases.name: Early Blight
diseases.definition: Early Blight is a common fungal disease affecting tomatoes and potatoes, caused by Alternaria solani.
diseases.history: Early Blight was first documented in the 19th century and continues to be a major concern for solanaceous crops.
diseases.symptoms: Symptoms include dark, concentric rings on older leaves, which can lead to significant defoliation.
diseases.causes: The fungus thrives in warm, wet conditions and spreads through splashing water and infected plant debris.
diseases.solutions: Solutions include removing infected plant debris, using resistant varieties, and applying fungicides.

diseases.name: Healthy
diseases.definition: A state in which plants exhibit optimal growth and show no signs of disease or pest infestation.
diseases.history: Healthy plants have been a goal of agriculture since the beginning of farming.
diseases.symptoms: Healthy plants display vigorous growth, green leaves, and high productivity.
diseases.causes: Healthy plants result from proper care, adequate nutrition, and favorable growing conditions.
diseases.solutions: Maintain plant health through regular monitoring, proper watering, balanced fertilization, and pest management.

diseases.name: Late Blight
diseases.definition: Late Blight is a destructive disease of potatoes and tomatoes caused by the oomycete Phytophthora infestans.
diseases.history: Late Blight was responsible for the Irish Potato Famine in the mid-19th century.
diseases.symptoms: Symptoms include water-soaked lesions on leaves and stems, which rapidly turn brown and black.
diseases.causes: The disease is caused by Phytophthora infestans, which spreads through cool, wet conditions.
diseases.solutions: Control measures include using resistant varieties, applying fungicides, and removing infected plant material.

diseases.name: Leaf Mold
diseases.definition: Leaf Mold is a fungal disease primarily affecting tomatoes, caused by the fungus Passalora fulva.
diseases.history: First identified in the early 20th century, Leaf Mold has been a significant issue in greenhouse tomato production.
diseases.symptoms: Symptoms include yellow spots on upper leaf surfaces and grayish-brown mold on the undersides.
diseases.causes: The fungus thrives in high humidity and poor air circulation, spreading through spores.
diseases.solutions: Solutions include improving air circulation, reducing humidity, and applying fungicides.

diseases.name: Septoria
diseases.definition: Septoria Leaf Spot is a fungal disease affecting tomatoes, caused by Septoria lycopersici.
diseases.history: Septoria Leaf Spot has been recognized as a common tomato disease since the late 19th century.
diseases.symptoms: Symptoms include small, circular spots with dark borders on leaves, leading to premature leaf drop.
diseases.causes: The fungus spreads through water splashes and contaminated plant debris.
diseases.solutions: Management includes removing infected leaves, using resistant varieties, and applying fungicides.

diseases.name: Spider Mites
diseases.definition: Spider Mites are tiny arthropods that infest plants, causing significant damage by feeding on plant cells.
diseases.history: Spider Mites have been a known pest in agriculture for centuries, affecting a wide range of plants.
diseases.symptoms: Symptoms include stippling, yellowing, and webbing on leaves, which can lead to plant stress and reduced yield.
diseases.causes: Infestations are caused by various species of mites, thriving in hot, dry conditions.
diseases.solutions: Control measures include using miticides, introducing natural predators, and maintaining adequate humidity.

diseases.name: Yellow Leaf Curl Virus
diseases.definition: Yellow Leaf Curl Virus is a viral disease affecting tomatoes, transmitted by the whitefly Bemisia tabaci.
diseases.history: First identified in the mid-20th century, the virus has become widespread, causing significant crop losses.
diseases.symptoms: Symptoms include yellowing and curling of leaves, stunted growth, and reduced fruit set.
diseases.causes: The virus is transmitted by the whitefly vector, which spreads the virus from infected to healthy plants.
diseases.solutions: Management includes controlling whitefly populations, using resistant varieties, and implementing good sanitation practices.
